Agreed. I was a grown up when I married and had children. Although I didn't really understand how it would change my life, I knew it would, that my priorities would shift considerably, and that I'd have a new person whose interest would take precedence over mine.

Duh!

But then, unlike the author I did not lose any of my previous roles, but only added to them. I kept my job and other responsibilities and blended the Mama (no Mommy at our house) stuff into the mix. The new normal, for the most part, suited us just fine.

Being a mother is not the only defining role in my life, but it is a very big one. As it should be for anyone taking on the task.

You missed my point. If you want to do something about CO2 emissions, your FIRST STEP should be to limit population growth.

If you don't do that, global warming is insoluble. Moreover, global warming is the least of your problems.

You think mere pollution is bad. Then contemplate the starvation of Somalia, the genocide of Rwanda, the suicide bombers of hopeless societies who regard death as an improvement. Except those problems will eventually come to roost right here in the US.

It is the height of insanity to disregard these problems, starvation, resource wars, pestilences brought about by population growth.

And then sanctimoniously proclaim: We will fight global warming by installing better smog devices, we will recapture CO2 emissions, we will reuse our paper bas at the store.

Those are minor actions compared to the effect of population growth which sets on a course to a Malthusian end state of high death rates and greatly diminished quality of life.

mannyv,

If your job depends on teaching to the test, that is what you do.

Why is that hard to understand?

All these complaints didn't exist when the privileged and State governments could game the system to their advantage. Suddenly, when there are standards to meet, all the suburban moms are horrified to learn that neither they not their children are all that bright.

You didn't take high stakes where students and teachers are evaluated by one test. Schools are given letter grades and receive or lose money and resources based on that score. You were educated not taught how to fill in bubbles. Times have changed.

I've taken multiple standardized tests during my lifetime, as well as the standard battery of quizzes, exams, term papers, etc. They were nothing compared to what you actually have to do in real life.

That said, none of my teachers actually taught to a standardized test. They tested what they taught, and the standardized tests took care of themselves.

If teachers are teaching to the test, they're doing it wrong - or they feel that their students are incapable of extracting information from their lessons, so they have to focus on the basics. It's unclear whether that's a failure of teaching, a realistic assessment of their student's ability, or some area in-between.

If teachers aren't teaching to the test, what are teachers teaching?

"Rejected" is a reversal clue. Communist (RED) party (DO) reversed is ODDER.  Or alternatively it's an anagram signal (which it sounds more like) where the anagram happens to be a reversal.  But with one dictionary definition of "reject" being "throw back; repulse" my assumption is that it was intended to be a reversal signal.

One of the difficulties for me is when 2 word phrases have become automatized to the point that I can't break them into two separate clues. In this case: (communist party) = red, but then where does "do" come from? Is there some communist group with initials "d o" that I'm not aware of?... The reversal part was clear from the start, but it wasn't until you you parsed the clue that I could see it as two words. Thanks!
25D?  I got everything else. Stranger = Odder, but I don't get it from the clue.

I really wonder to what extent any polity can address the harsh, long-term, structural problems that afflict Egypt:

1) No matter who rules that country, the regime cannot escape the reality that Egypt is overwhelmingly a desert country - more than 95% of its land mass.
2) Additionally, its population has exploded the last few decades, resulting in a large number of young, able-bodied men who lack employment opportunities, but who will exert stress on the environment.
3) Finally, the country's female population is largely excluded from economic participation, relegated to the home (although this would seem to be favoured by IS militants), and condemning Egypt to perennially under-perform and never attain its national potential (let alone result in unfulfilled lives for these women).

The Islamic State is, regrettably, highly attractive to many young male Muslims. But while these men appear to relish the opportunity to inflict death and destruction, and perhaps welcome death for themselves, I have to question how they could actually govern. This fervent sweeping the Islamic world is nihilistic in its blood-thirsty actions and appalling world view. But as with any revolution, there is always the issue of consolidation - not only having to contain "reaction" (returning to some form of the ancien regime), but also always having to worry about being outflanked by ever more radical elements (is the MB worried?), and to getting the trains to run on time.

Chess board is getting more complicated. The current air campaign to deflate IS command and control and train the Iraq military to stand up and fight is the appropriate approach. More US military on the ground generates more cash for local tribal leaders and politicians who have proven to be untrustworthy and self-serving - i.e.) Maliki. The merger of interest between the Egyptian terrorist faction and IS should put the Egyptian military on notice. Since they own most of the big cash flow enterprises in Egypt they have a vested interest in controlling free milk from the cow spilling into the hands of the zealots. Since there are great schisms between sectarian groups within the Middle East it would be difficult for them to form one big Caliphate in the absence of a monopoly over the cash flow. I suspect Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi is the front man for a band of thieves creaming off the oil revenues. The US/West's mission to avoid putting manpower into the fight - other than trainers and Special Ops recon missions, is a smart option to reduce corruption and encourage the locals to take ownership of the fight.

When people have their family lives and livelihood in the cross hairs of a violent enemy the incentive to defend oneself is first and foremost. Once you take away the need to fight and leave money on the table for the leadership to steal the natural order is disturbed and the end game becomes more complex and unmanageable. We seen that movie in slow motion.
